title.rendered: Explore Job Roles: Tax Examiners and Collectors

content.rendered:
What are Tax Examiners and Collectors?

Tax Examiners and Collectors figure out how much individuals and businesses owe in taxes.

Where do Tax Examiners and Collectors work?

  • Federal government
  • State government
  • Local government

How much do Tax Examiners and Collectors make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for Tax Examiners and Collectors is $42,000.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Tax Examiners and Collectors?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Accounting majors
  • Finance majors
  • Business majors
  • Criminal justice majors
Search Tax Examiner jobs on Handshake

Tax Examiner and Collector skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Tax Examiners and Collectors succeed in their work:

  • Comfortability with relevant computer softwares
  • Good people skills
  • Organizational skills

What are some common questions about Tax Examiners and Collectors?

Q: How do people become Tax Examiners?

A: For Tax Examiner positions, a relevant bachelor’s degree and prior experience
